elements.content: A versatile organic–inorganic hybrid structure makes a metal–organic framework (MOF) an outstanding host for different kinds of guests; in addition, its easy pyrolysis nature has been proven to be useful as precursors in the construction of carbon-based materials with a special porous structure. Herein, a novel porous composite nanostructure of an aminated MIL-53­(Al)@carbon nanotube (CNT) has been successfully constructed for the first time based on in situ synthesis combining the pyrolysis of ZIF-67. The resulting composite nanostructure was performed by the means of scanning electron microscopy, Brunauer–Emmett–Teller analysis, typical and high-resolution transmission electronic microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, etc. The results showed that a compact heterostructure has been formed between an aminated MIL-53­(Al) and a CNT. The resulting composites, named N-MIL@CNT, represent distinct promoted activities in the removal of Bisphenol AF (BPAF) and Metribuzin from wastewater, and the maximum adsorption values were 274 mg/g (BPAF) and 213 mg/g (Metribuzin), which are larger than the results obtained by other MOF-based nanomaterials. The adsorption isotherm, kinetics, and thermodynamics were studied in detail, and the selective adsorption mechanism was also suggested. The excellent selectivity, reusability, and structure stability suggest the potential application of this composite nanostructure in the selective removal of BPAF or Metribuzin from the practical wastewater.

elements.content: Herein, we constructed the nanocomposites of N-MIL@CNT via a simple procedure combining the pyrolysis of ZIF-67 for the first time. The resulting nanocomposites combined the surface affinity of aminated MIL-53­(Al) and the porous channel of a carbon nanotube, thus representing the excellent adsorption selectivity and best adsorption uptake for Bisphenol AF (274.0 mg/g) and Metribuzin (213.2 mg/g) compared to the most reported results related to the metal−organic framework-based materials. The interface weak interactions including hydrogen-bonding and π−π-stacking forces could be controlled to regulate the adsorption activity and selectivity.

The interface weak interactions including hydrogen-bonding and π-π-stacking forces could be controlled to regulate the adsorption activity and selectivity.

elements.content: Bisphenol AF (BPAF) is a very important component in the manufacturing industries of electronic devices, optical fibers, and food processing equipment, but it is also thought to be one of endocrine-disrupting chemicals because of its irreversible influence on the physical health of humans and wildlife by binding to hormone receptors. Metribuzin is another one of the most widely used aromatic compounds featured in high chemical stability, existing for up to 120 days in the environment, but which is also considered to be more toxic than other triazinone series compounds to algae, large plants, and aquatic plants. Both BPAF and Metribuzin cannot be biodegraded or chemically decomposed, which makes them great hazards toward environmental safety and human health. Therefore, developing an efficient separation technology for such synthetic persistent organics is of major concern, and several technologies such as ion exchange, membrane filtration, photocatalytic degradation, advanced oxidation, and solid-phase extraction have been explored to eliminate toxic organics from wastewater. Among these procedures, solid-phase extraction is one of the most probable technologies because of its high efficiency and feasibility, relatively low cost, and lower number of bioproducts. Different types of adsorption materials [silica beads, activated carbon, clay, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), imprinted polymers, and zeolites] were applied in the removal/adsorption of toxic organics. Great progress has been made in this kind of research. However, practical applications of these adsorbent materials are limited because of some inherent disadvantages, such as relatively low adsorption capacity and adsorption selectivity. Therefore, fabricating novel adsorbents that efficiently remove synthetic organics from wastewater is still an imperative desirable work.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Bisphenol AF (BPAF) is a very important component in the manufacturing industries of electronic devices, optical fibers, and food processing equipment, but it is also thought to be one of endocrine-disrupting chemicals because of its irreversible influence on the physical health of humans and wildlife by binding to hormone receptors. Metribuzin is another one of the most widely used aromatic compounds featured in high chemical stability, existing for up to 120 days in the environment, but which is also considered to be more toxic than other triazinone series compounds to algae, large plants, and aquatic plants. Both BPAF and Metribuzin cannot be biodegraded or chemically decomposed, which makes them great hazards toward environmental safety and human health. Therefore, developing an efficient separation technology for such synthetic persistent organics is of major concern, and several technologies such as ion exchange, membrane filtration, photocatalytic degradation, advanced oxidation, and solid-phase extraction have been explored to eliminate toxic organics from wastewater. Among these procedures, solid-phase extraction is one of the most probable technologies because of its high efficiency and feasibility, relatively low cost, and lower number of bioproducts. Different types of adsorption materials [silica beads, activated carbon, clay, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), imprinted polymers, and zeolites] were applied in the removal/adsorption of toxic organics. Great progress has been made in this kind of research. However, practical applications of these adsorbent materials are limited because of some inherent disadvantages, such as relatively low adsorption capacity and adsorption selectivity. Therefore, fabricating novel adsorbents that efficiently remove synthetic organics from wastewater is still an imperative desirable work.

elements.content: Compared to ordinary nanoadsorbents, porous or hollow nanostructures exhibit higher adsorption efficiency and faster adsorption rate thanks to their large surface area values, kinetically favorable open active sites, and surface reachability. MOFs as important three-dimensional porous nanomaterials feature adjustable pore size, available pore inner sites, and outer-surface functionality, which facilitate their structure design, controlled synthesis, and also elucidation of the structure–property relationship. Recently, there are several reports related to the usability of MOFs in the efficient removal of pollutants from solutions. In our previous work, the composite nanoadsorbent NH2-mSiO2@MIL-101­(Cr) was used to efficiently remove lead­(II) or chromium­(VI) in higher adsorption uptake. However, studies of the MOFs with respect to the selective adsorption of persistent organics are still limited and also suffer from challenges such as unsatisfactory adsorption capacity, moderate affinity/selectivity, and structural instability. To solve these problems, MOFs coupled with other functional nanomaterials seem to be good candidates. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs), a famous member of the carbon family, feature special hollow and porous nanotubes that are helpful in shortening the transport distance for target molecules from solutions to the surface. Furthermore, their porous walls also make it possible to anchor another functional adsorbent onto them and thus promote the adsorption uptake within a short time because of the synergy effect.

elements.content: Chemical vapor deposition and laser ablation are traditional methods to synthesize CNTs. Despite the great progress made in CNT synthesis, their relatively higher cost and larger energy consumption as well as complicated synthesis procedure limit further applications of CNTs. Recently, MOFs as the more beneficial precursors and templates exhibit superiority in the synthesis of metal–hybrid carbon-based materials. Specifically, zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) having better chemical stability and more easily controlled synthesis are considered to be more promising candidates in the preparation of derived carbon-based nanomaterials. However, there are no previous reports focused on hybridizing MOFs with CNT via the pyrolysis of ZIF-67 in the synthesis of CNTs.
elements.clean_text: Chemical vapor deposition and laser ablation are traditional methods to synthesize CNTs. Despite the great progress made in CNT synthesis, their relatively higher cost and larger energy consumption as well as complicated synthesis procedure limit further applications of CNTs. Recently, MOFs as the more beneficial precursors and templates exhibit superiority in the synthesis of metal-hybrid carbon-based materials. Specifically, zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) having better chemical stability and more easily controlled synthesis are considered to be more promising candidates in the preparation of derived carbon-based nanomaterials. However, there are no previous reports focused on hybridizing MOFs with CNT via the pyrolysis of ZIF-67 in the synthesis of CNTs.

elements.content: Inspired by the above-mentioned points, in this work, we synthesized aminated MIL-53­(Al) hybrid CNT nanocomposites using a relatively simple procedure. CNT was synthesized through the pyrolysis of ZIF-67, which was then utilized in the in situ hydrothermal production of aminated MIL-53­(Al). The resulting nanocomposites feature heterojunction structures between sheetlike aminated MIL-53­(Al) and CNT, which were then proven to be helpful for the improved adsorption activity and selectivity. Two persistent organics including BPAF and Metribuzin were selected as the targets in assessing the adsorption activity of the resulting composite nanoadsorbents, and comparative tests were also performed to verify the superiority of the resulting composite structure. The sorption isotherms, kinetics, and thermodynamics were investigated, and the selective adsorption mechanism was also determined. This work provides a new synthesis procedure for MOFs@CNT nanocomposites and also develops applications of the MOF@CNT composite nanostructures in the selective removal of organic pollutants from wastewater.

Two persistent organics including BPAF and Metribuzin were selected as the targets in assessing the adsorption activity of the resulting composite nanoadsorbents, and comparative tests were also performed to verify the superiority of the resulting composite structure. elements.content: The whole synthetic process for aminated MIL-53­(Al) @CNT is explained in . ZIF-67 was prepared based on a former report. Typically, Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (1.644 g, 5.65 mmol) was added to methanol (80 mL), into which a solution of 2-methylimidazole (3.7 g, 45 mmol) and 80 mL of methanol was added. After stirring 24 h at 25 °C, ZIF-67 particles were obtained, washed with methanol, and then dried at 60 °C under vacuum. The pyrolysis of ZIF-67 follows the literal work. ZIF-67 was treated at 800 °C, kept for 2 h under a N2 atmosphere at 4 °C/min, then naturally cooled to room temperature to obtain cobalt-containing CNT (Co@CNT).
elements.clean_text:
Experiments

Synthesis of an Aminated MIL-53(Al)@CNT

The whole synthetic process for aminated MIL-53(Al) @CNT is explained in . ZIF-67 was prepared based on a former report. Typically, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1.644 g, 5.65 mmol) was added to methanol (80 mL), into which a solution of 2-methylimidazole (3.7 g, 45 mmol) and 80 mL of methanol was added. After stirring 24 h at 25 °C, ZIF-67 particles were obtained, washed with methanol, and then dried at 60 °C under vacuum. The pyrolysis of ZIF-67 follows the literal work. ZIF-67 was treated at 800 °C, kept for 2 h under a N2 atmosphere at 4 °C/min, then naturally cooled to room temperature to obtain cobalt-containing CNT (Co@CNT).

elements.content: Aminated MIL-53­(Al)@CNT (labeled as N-MIL@CNT) was prepared based on a modified reported procedure. A total of 30 mg of Co@CNT was fully dispersed in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) under sonication, and then aminoisophthalic acid (NH2-BDC; 4.14 mmol, 0.75 g), AlCl3·6H2O (4.14 mmol, 1.0 g), and poly­(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP; 1.5 × 10–3 mmol, 60 mg) were added. After the mixed solution was stirred for 1 h, it was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-sealed autoclave and heat-treated at 140 °C for 24 h. The products were separated and washed by DMF to remove cobalt nanoparticles.

elements.content: Two synthetic organics, BPAF and Metribuzin, were selected as targets to measure the adsorption activities of prepared N-MIL@CNT, and the contrast experiments were also conducted on pristine Co@CNT and aminated MIL-53­(Al). The batch adsorption experiments were based on the following procedure: 5 mg of adsorbent was dissolved in a 8 mL solution containing a definite content of organics, and the resulting mixture was stirred at a specific temperature for a certain time. The suspension was obtained regularly and centrifuged, and the concentrations of the organics were confirmed using the working curves based on its absorbency at maximum wavelengths of 271 nm (BPAF) and 293 nm (Metribuzin), separately.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Studies

Two synthetic organics, BPAF and Metribuzin, were selected as targets to measure the adsorption activities of prepared N-MIL@CNT, and the contrast experiments were also conducted on pristine Co@CNT and aminated MIL-53(Al). The batch adsorption experiments were based on the following procedure: 5 mg of adsorbent was dissolved in a 8 mL solution containing a definite content of organics, and the resulting mixture was stirred at a specific temperature for a certain time. The suspension was obtained regularly and centrifuged, and the concentrations of the organics were confirmed using the working curves based on its absorbency at maximum wavelengths of 271 nm (BPAF) and 293 nm (Metribuzin), separately.

elements.content: The reusability was measured by adding 5 mg of N-MIL@CNT to a 8 mL solution containing 10 mg/L organics. After each adsorption, the adsorbents were centrifuged, eluted by ethanol (10 mL), ultrasonically treated for about 15 min, and then reused in the above adsorption and desorption tests to investigate their cyclic adsorption performances.

elements.content: The morphology observation of the prepared particles is expressed in and S1. ZIF-67 (Figure S1a) looks like a diamond dodecahedron, the average side length of which is 200 nm. After calcination at 800 °C under a N2 atmosphere, a lot of the tube structure could be found on the surface of the diamond dodecahedron particles (a,b), and the nanotube diameter is about 3 nm on average (inset in b). The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of the resulting CNT represents two kinds of lattice structures: one with an interplanar spacing of 0.34 nm ascribed to the lattice plane (111) of metallic cobalt (JCPDS 15-0806) and the other one with d = 0.21 nm attributed to the plane (002) of graphitic carbon, which determines the generation of Co@CNT based on the pyrolysis of ZIF-67. The original aminated MIL-53­(Al) is irregular-shaped with a size of about 150 nm (Figure S1b). While aminated MIL-53­(Al) is synthesized in Co@CNT, as shown in d and S1c,d, lamellar-shaped MIL-53­(Al) with an average side length of about 200 nm is observed, and the compact heterostructure is produced between CNT and lamellar-shaped MIL-53­(Al). The inset in d illustrates the possible construction of a N-MIL@CNT composite nanostructure. The morphology changes of MIL-53­(Al) may be caused by the presence of CNT in the formation of MIL-53­(Al); in that case, heterogeneous nucleation instead of homogeneous nucleation may be conducted, and CNT acts as part of the nucleation center. A similar dependence is also reported in the synthesis of ZIF-8 in the presence of CNT, and the spherical-like ZIF-8 with smaller size is ornamented around the CNT sidewall, leading to the creation of a hierarchical pore structure. The elemental composition of N-MIL@CNT is given in Figure S1f, in which there are four elements (Al, N, O, and C), and the relative atomic percentages of C, N, O, and Al are 70.49%, 9.47%, 17.76%, and 2.22%, respectively. The Co cannot be found in the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy profile, indicating that Co may be removed in the construction of N-MIL@CNT due to HCl produced in the corresponding hydrothermal process.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structure Characterization

The morphology observation of the prepared particles is expressed in  and S1. ZIF-67 (Figure S1a) looks like a diamond dodecahedron, the average side length of which is 200 nm. After calcination at 800 °C under a N2 atmosphere, a lot of the tube structure could be found on the surface of the diamond dodecahedron particles (a,b), and the nanotube diameter is about 3 nm on average (inset in b). The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of the resulting CNT represents two kinds of lattice structures: one with an interplanar spacing of 0.34 nm ascribed to the lattice plane (111) of metallic cobalt (JCPDS 15-0806) and the other one with d = 0.21 nm attributed to the plane (002) of graphitic carbon, which determines the generation of Co@CNT based on the pyrolysis of ZIF-67. The original aminated MIL-53(Al) is irregular-shaped with a size of about 150 nm (Figure S1b). While aminated MIL-53(Al) is synthesized in Co@CNT, as shown in d and S1c,d, lamellar-shaped MIL-53(Al) with an average side length of about 200 nm is observed, and the compact heterostructure is produced between CNT and lamellar-shaped MIL-53(Al). The inset in d illustrates the possible construction of a N-MIL@CNT composite nanostructure. The morphology changes of MIL-53(Al) may be caused by the presence of CNT in the formation of MIL-53(Al); in that case, heterogeneous nucleation instead of homogeneous nucleation may be conducted, and CNT acts as part of the nucleation center. A similar dependence is also reported in the synthesis of ZIF-8 in the presence of CNT, and the spherical-like ZIF-8 with smaller size is ornamented around the CNT sidewall, leading to the creation of a hierarchical pore structure. The elemental composition of N-MIL@CNT is given in Figure S1f, in which there are four elements (Al, N, O, and C), and the relative atomic percentages of C, N, O, and Al are 70.49%, 9.47%, 17.76%, and 2.22%, respectively. The Co cannot be found in the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy profile, indicating that Co may be removed in the construction of N-MIL@CNT due to HCl produced in the corresponding hydrothermal process.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns also prove the successful construction of N-MIL@CNT. In Figure S2, for Co@CNT, the main diffraction peaks around 44.0° and 52.0° correspond to metallic cobalt (JCPDS 15-0806), and another relative weak diffraction at 26.1° is indexed to graphitic carbon. There is no diffraction belonging to ZIF-67, proving the complete decomposition of ZIF-67. As for aminated MIL-53­(Al), the diffraction located at 2θ = 9.2° is matched with the lattice plane (110), and another diffraction at 2θ = 18.4° is caused by overlap diffraction by the lattice planes (211) and (220). In comparison with that of aminated MIL-53­(Al), the main peaks of N-MIL@CNT at 9.2° and 18.4° are well matched with those of aminated MIL-53­(Al). The diffraction of CNT and cobalt determining the low content or poor crystallinity of CNT and the disappearance of cobalt metal in the synthesis process of N-MIL@CNT are hardly discovered.

elements.content: Chemical bonding in N-MIL@CNT is evidenced by Fourier transform infrared analyses (a). For Co@CNT, the absorption bands at 3442 and 1627 cm–1 can be ascribed to O–H bonding aroused by either the physically adsorbed water or surface hydroxylation of the as-produced CNT. For aminated MIL-53­(Al), the characteristic absorption peaks assigned to −NH2 are found at 3504,  3375, and 1596 cm–1, the IR peaks at 1409 cm–1 are designated as C–N bending, and the peak at around 1666 cm–1 corresponds to CO of the remaining DMF. Compared to pristine CNT and aminated MIL-53­(Al), all adsorption peaks in the IR pattern of N-MIL@CNT are attributed to the stretching or scissoring bands of −NH2, −CN, −OH, and −CO, being in accordance with IR absorption of CNT and aminated MIL-53­(Al). Interestingly, the relative intensive absorption appearing at 1677 cm–1, aroused from CO, is enhanced significantly, which may be caused by the increased uncoordinated −COOH groups contrasting with aminated MIL-53­(Al).

elements.content: The chemical compositions of the as-obtained Co@CNT and N-MIL@CNT were determined by applying X-ray photoelectron spctroscopy (XPS) analyses. The broad XPS profile of Co@CNT (Figure S3a) exhibits Co, O, C, and N elements. The XPS pattern of Co 2p (Figure S3b) can be divided into three peaks: 778.5 eV is of zerovalent Co, and 780.7 and 795.6 eV are of CoO. The C 1s XPS pattern, shown in Figure S3c, deconvoluted as three distinct peaks: the main peak (284.4 eV) is attributed to graphitic layers (C–C and CC), the second peak (285.2 eV) is assigned to CN, and the third peak (286.3 eV) is ascribed to C atoms being bonded directly to oxygen (C–O). c shows that N-MIL@CNT composites contain the elements O, N, C, and Al. Interestingly, no peaks ascribed to element Co dedicate to the removal of Co in the construction procedure of N-MIL@CNT owing to the HCl produced during the hydrothermal process. The C 1s XPS spectrum (d) can also be divided into the following peaks: one peak at 288.8 eV corresponds to carboxyl, and the other peaks found at 284.7 and 285.3 eV correspond to C–O and C–C. The corresponding O 1s XPS spectrum (e) describes two peaks: one at 532.3 eV belongs to CO, and another one centered at 533.2 eV comes from the Al–O bond. In addition, the N 1s XPS profile (f) shows two major peaks at 399.7 and 400.7 eV assigned to C–N and PhNH2 of the organic linker in the framework, respectively.

The broad XPS profile of Co@CNT (Figure S3a) exhibits Co, O, C, and N elements. The XPS pattern of Co 2p (Figure S3b) can be divided into three peaks: 778.5 eV is of zerovalent Co, and 780.7 and 795.6 eV are of CoO. The C 1s XPS pattern, shown in Figure S3c, deconvoluted as three distinct peaks: the main peak (284.4 eV) is attributed to graphitic layers (C-C and CC), the second peak (285.2 eV) is assigned to CN, and the third peak (286.3 eV) is ascribed to C atoms being bonded directly to oxygen (C-O). c shows that N-MIL@CNT composites contain the elements O, N, C, and Al. Interestingly, no peaks ascribed to element Co dedicate to the removal of Co in the construction procedure of N-MIL@CNT owing to the HCl produced during the hydrothermal process. The C 1s XPS spectrum (d) can also be divided into the following peaks: one peak at 288.8 eV corresponds to carboxyl, and the other peaks found at 284.7 and 285.3 eV correspond to C-O and C-C. The corresponding O 1s XPS spectrum (e) describes two peaks: one at 532.3 eV belongs to CO, and another one centered at 533.2 eV comes from the Al-O bond. In addition, the N 1s XPS profile (f) shows two major peaks at 399.7 and 400.7 eV assigned to C-N and PhNH2 of the organic linker in the framework, respectively.

elements.content: The representative N2 sorption isotherm and corresponding pore size are depicted in g,h,i. The N2 sorption curves display a combined type I/IV sorption isotherm, implying the existence of both micropores and mesopores in Co@CNT, aminated MIL-53­(Al), and N-MIL@CNT. Furthermore, comparing the N2 adsorption–desorption curves of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) and N-MIL@CNT, we can find increased micropores and mesopores in N-MIL@CNT, and a distinct H4-type hysteresis loop at p/p 2 of more than 0.45 also indicated stacked pores by the lamellar structure in N-MIL@CNT. According to the corresponding pore-size distribution profile of N-MIL@CNT, there are mesopores centered at 2.5 nm in addition to the micropores. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) values of Co@CNT, aminated MIL-53­(Al), and N-MIL@CNT are 311.2, 319.1, and 811.1 m2/g, and the total pore volumes are 0.450, 0.574, and 0.662 cm3/g respectively. It should be noticed that the BET value and pore volume of N-MIL@CNT are both clearly larger than the values of aminated MIL-53 (Al) and Co@CNT, implying increased open channels and pores, which are beneficial for organics adsorption.

elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Study

The mesoporous structure allows N-MIL@CNT to adsorb the relatively large guest molecules, and the functional -NH2 groups make them compatible with some guest molecule containing -NH2 or -OH via hydrogen bonding. Two persistent organic pollutants, BPAF and Metribuzin, molecular structures of which are shown in Figure S4, were selected to assess the adsorption activity of the resulting N-MIL@CNT. Metribuzin has terminal -NH2, and BPAF has the -OH group, both of which have aromatic rings. The condition-dependent adsorption experiments were conducted to optimize the experimental parameters.

elements.content: First, the influence of the quantities of Co@CNT on the surface adsorption of the resulting N-MIL@CNT is described as . As represented in , while the added amounts of Co@CNT increased from 0 to 100 mg in the hydrothermal generation of final composites, the adsorption capacities of the two organics show similar dependencies featured in first increased and then redecreased values, which demonstrates that proper hybridization of Co@CNT can reach the maximum surface adsorption activity. The optimum added amount of 30 mg is the most beneficial for obtaining the best adsorption results.

elements.content: Adsorption amounts of BPAF and Metribuzin related to the loading amounts of Co@CNT.
elements.clean_text: 3  Adsorption amounts of BPAF and Metribuzin related to the loading amounts of Co@CNT.

elements.content: The pH effects on the adsorption amounts of the two organics are displayed in a. Notably, the pH value has almost no influence on the adsorption capacities of Metribuzin but a relatively apparent influence on the BPAF adsorption. For instance, the adsorption quantities of BPAF decrease slightly as the pH was changed from 3.0 to 8.0 and then clearly decreased when the pH went over 8.0. This phenomenon can be interpreted by the deprotonation of BPAF in alkaline conditions, which may restrain interaction at the interface of BPAF/N-MIL@CNT with the lack of hydrogen bonding. Comparatively, insensitivity to the pH values for the adsorption of Metribuzin suggests that hydrophobic interaction rather than electrostatic attraction plays a role in this adsorption process. Taking into account that the industrial wastewater is usually neutral, the pH adjustment is omitted in the following procedures.

elements.content: To further prove that hydrophobic interaction or hydrogen bonding rather than electrostatic attraction worked in these adsorption procedures, the influence of the ionic strength was measured. With regard to b, the sorption capacities of both organics remained almost unchanged as the ionic concentrations increased, which can be elucidated by the neglectable function of electrostatic force in this adsorption procedure.

elements.content: The adsorption kinetics are recorded at a changed temperature to further investigate the adsorption mechanism. As shown in a,b, the adsorption rates for BPAF and Metribuzin are fast in the first 100 min, then increased slowly, and finally reached adsorption equilibrium at 180 min. The adsorption kinetics are also influenced by the temperature, and the adsorption rate increased at increased temperature ranging from 25 to 45 °C. The positive relationship between the sorption rate and temperature permitted an endothermic process. At elevated temperature, the molecular diffusion of organics is accelerated, and as a result, the surface of the adsorbents can more easily be reached.

elements.content: PVP usually acts as the structure-directing and stabilizing agent in the synthesis of fine particles. In this work, PVP worked in the hydrothermal production of N-MIL@CNT, which was expected to help in the formation of a homogeneous structure. To further study the important roles of PVP, contrast adsorption tests were carried out by aminated MIL-53­(Al)/PVP and CNT/PVP, and the sorption results are shown in Figure S5. According to Figure S5a, the capacity of BPAF on CNT/PVP is 90 mg/g, lower than that on a single CNT (173.0 mg/g), with the value on aminated MIL-53­(Al)/PVP being 92.4 mg/g, higher than the results on aminated MIL-53­(Al) (62.3 mg/g) but lower than the value on N-MIL@CNT (269.0 mg/g). The same relationship was also observed in the contrast tests of Metribuzin on aminate MIL-53­(Al)/PVP and CNT/PVP. The above blank tests prove that PVP mainly worked with aminated MIL-53­(Al) and has a positive effect on its adsorption activities. PVP is an amphiphilic polymer that has been widely used to stabilize nanoparticles including MOFs with various structures to regulate particles’ shapes and sizes. The morphology comparison of aminated MIL-53­(Al) with PVP (Figure S1e) and without PVP (Figure S1b) demonstrates that more uniform particles are synthesized in the presence of PVP.

elements.content: The fitting results (a–f) show that the good linear relationship was received according to the quasi-second-order pattern for both organics. Table S1 summarizes the calculated simulating parameters. It is clear that the highest correlation values R 2 are obtained by the quasi-second order pattern, and the corresponding equilibrium adsorption capacity (q e) is also closer to the experimental values than those obtained when two other kinetics equations are employed. Being more applicable to the quasi-second-order model implies that the chemical sorption mainly works in the adsorption process for both organics by N-MIL@CNT.

elements.content: To estimate the theoretical maximum adsorption capacity, the sorption isotherms of the two organics were performed. With regard to a,b, the maximum equilibrium sorption capacities of BPAF are 175 mg/g (Co@CNT), 67 mg/g [aminated MIL-53­(Al)], and 270 mg/g (N-MIL@CNT), the values of which for Metribuzin are 85, 64, and 206 mg/g, respectively. The adsorption isotherms of the two organics by ZIF-67 were also measured, and the results are given in Figure S6. The maximum adsorption capacities of both organics are 47 mg/g (BPAF) and 12 mg/g (Metribuzin). Obviously, compared to the single component, N-MIL@CNT represents the excellent enhanced adsorption performance, which may result from the synergistic effect of the large open cavities of CNT and high affinity of aminated MIL-53­(Al).

elements.content: To prove such a synergistic effect, we also used the mechanical mixture of the pure CNT and aminated MIL-53­(Al) as comparative adsorbents to adsorb the organics under the same conditions, and the adsorption results are recorded in Figure S7. A 330 mg portion of CNT/aminated MIL-53­(Al) (30 mg/300 mg) could adsorb 56 mg/g of BPAF and 53 mg/g of Metribuzin under the same conditions, which are much lower than the adsorption efficiency by prepared composites, proving that hybridization of the aminated MIL-53­(Al) in CNT is a favorable method to improve adsorption toward the organics from water based on the compact heterostructure.

The two equations are described as follows: c e q e = c e q max + 1 q max K L ln ⁡ q e = ln ⁡ K F + 1 n ⁡ ln ⁡ c e among which c e and q e are the organics’ concentrations and adsorption capacity at equilibrium, q max represents the theoretical adsorption capacity, and n relates to the surface heterogeneity factor.

elements.content: Parts c–f of show the fitting curves replotted according to the Langmuir and Freundlich formulas, and the calculated isotherm constants are illustrated in . The highest correlation coefficients (R 2) and the closer values for the theoretical q max and experimental q e prove that the Langmuir pattern is more applicable for the two organics’ adsorption on N-MIL@CNT, and the theoretical q max values are 274 mg/g (BPAF) and 213.2 mg/g (Metribuzin), respectively. These results are larger than the formerly reported adsorption results of BPAF or Metribuzin by other adsorbents. For example, multiwalled CNT and chitosan-modified zeolite can adsorb BPAF with capacities of 88.89 and 26.2 mg/g; Metribuzin was absorbed by switch grass biochar and Mag-H+ with values of 151 and 65 mg/g.

Adsorption Thermodynamics

The sorption thermodynamic constants involving the standard Gibbs free energy (ΔG ⊖, kJ/mol), entropy change (ΔS ⊖, J/mol⋅K), and enthalpy change (ΔH ⊖, kJ/mol) can be inferred from -: 8       K   D   =     q   e       c   e          9     ln ⁡   K   D   = -   Δ   H   ⊖     R T   +   Δ   S   ⊖     R        10     Δ   G   ⊖   = Δ   H   ⊖   - T Δ   S   ⊖      in which K D is the distribution ratio, R equals to 8.314 J/mol⋅K, T is the temperature in Kelvin, and q e and c e are the adsorption capacity and concentration at equilibrium, respectively.

elements.content: The replotting profiles of ln K D ∼ 1/T are shown in Figure S8, and ΔH ⊖ and ΔS ⊖ can be inferred from the slope and intercept data; thus, ΔG ⊖ is obtained according to . The calculated thermodynamic values are included in . This shows that the sorption of the two organics is featured in an endothermic, entropy-increasing, and spontaneous process between the temperatures of 298 and 318 K.

Given the coexistence of interferential ions in the wastewater, the effects of some commonly encountered cationic and anionic ions (i.e., NO3 –, Cl–, SO4 2–, Mg2+, Ni2+, K+, Zn2+, Cu2+) with a concentration of 1 × 10–3 mol/L upon removal of BPAF (3 × 10–4 mol/L) by N-MIL@CNT could be assessed.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Selectivity and Adsorption Mechanism

Given the coexistence of interferential ions in the wastewater, the effects of some commonly encountered cationic and anionic ions (i.e., NO3 -, Cl-, SO4 2-, Mg2+, Ni2+, K+, Zn2+, Cu2+) with a concentration of 1 × 10-3 mol/L upon removal of BPAF (3 × 10-4 mol/L) by N-MIL@CNT could be assessed.

elements.content: As displayed in a, most of the ions except Cu2+ have no significant negative impact on the BPAF adsorption, which can be well retained above 78% of the original value obtained without coexisting ions. The influence of other phenol organics (i.e., phenol, resorcinol, 3-aminophenol) on the BPAF adsorption was also studied to further verify the selectivity. As shown in b, the adsorption capacities are 159.5 mg/g (BPAF), 9.8 mg/g (phenol), 5.9 mg/g (resorcinol), and 11.8 mg/g (3-aminophenol). The excellent adsorption selectivity for BPAF by the as-constructed N-MIL@CNT is well presented, mainly thanks to the high affinity of aminated MIL-53­(Al) with BPAF via hydrogen bonding as well as the interface synergy brought by the compact heterostructure. In addition, we also conducted selective adsorption studies on Metribuzin. As presented in Figure S9, the adsorption capacities are 150.0 mg/g (Metribuzin), 15.9 mg/g (Tartrazine), 14.0 mg/g (Acid Blue 90), and 16.2 mg/g (Acid Blue 1). The excellent adsorption selectivity for Metribuzin could be explained by hydrogen bonding between Metribuzin and N-MIL@CNT.

elements.content: Considering the similar aromatic structures of the two organics and N-MIL@CNT, the hydrophobic interactions might also work in the sorption procedure. The water contact angle of N-MIL@CNT is about 95.6° (Figure S10), the value of which is higher than that of an ordinary hydrophobic membrane, such as a poly­(vinylidene fluoride) membrane, indicating the strong hydrophobic nature of N-MIL@CNT composite particles. Because of the octanol/water partition coefficients of different phenols (4.47 for BPAF, 1.46 for phenol, 0.88 for resorcinol, and 0.15 for 3-aminophenol), the strongest hydrophobic interaction may exist between BPAF and N-MIL@CNT, which is also responsible to the best BPAF adsorption by N-MIL@CNT.

The water contact angle of N-MIL@CNT is about 95.6° (Figure S10), the value of which is higher than that of an ordinary hydrophobic membrane, such as a poly(vinylidene fluoride) membrane, indicating the strong hydrophobic nature of N-MIL@CNT composite particles. Because of the octanol/water partition coefficients of different phenols (4.47 for BPAF, 1.46 for phenol, 0.88 for resorcinol, and 0.15 for 3-aminophenol), the strongest hydrophobic interaction may exist between BPAF and N-MIL@CNT, which is also responsible to the best BPAF adsorption by N-MIL@CNT.

elements.content: Furthermore, to confirm the selective adsorption mechanism of N-MIL@CNT, XPS analyses were also conducted. As displayed in a, the full-scale XPS pattern of N-MIL@CNT before the adsorption shows Al, O, C, and N elements; after BPAF adsorption, the additional peaks attributed to element F appeared; meanwhile with absorbed Metribuzin, the S element is represented, which proves the successful sorption of BPAF and Metribuzin conducted on N-MIL@CNT. As related to the N 1s XPS profile in b, the binding energies of N 1s for N-MIL@CNT before the adsorption tests are located at 399.7 and 400.7 eV, assigned to C–N and Ph–NH2, while upon inclusion of BPAF and Metribuzin, the peak assigned to Ph–NH2 shifts to higher binding energies of 400.1 eV (with BPAF) and 400.3 eV (with Metribuzin), which can be aroused by the production of hydrogen bonding between organic molecules and N-MIL@CNT, resulting in a forward polarization of nitrogen bearing a larger binding energy.

elements.content: As mentioned above, the selective adsorption mechanisms toward BPAF and Metribuzin for N-MIL@CNT can be summarized as follows (): (1) Evident increased BET areas and increased mesopores of N-MIL@CNT in contrast to single components provide much more active sites and can more easily emigrate into the pores. In addition, the lamellar structure of N-MIL@CNT is also helpful in suppressing mass-transfer resistance and thus promoting the adsorption of organics. (2) Hydrophobic interactions as well as π–π stacking exist between hydrophobic N-MIL@CNT and aromatic organic molecules. (3) Hydrogen bonding is generated between aminated MIL-53­(Al) and organics containing the terminal −NH2 or −OH groups. (4) Interface synergy exists because of the active open cavities of CNT and the high affinity of aminated MIL-53­(Al) facing organic molecules. The differences in the strength of the above interactions are responsible for the selective adsorption of various organic molecules, while they were adsorbed on the as-constructed N-MIL@CNT composites.

In addition, the lamellar structure of N-MIL@CNT is also helpful in suppressing mass-transfer resistance and thus promoting the adsorption of organics. (2) Hydrophobic interactions as well as π-π stacking exist between hydrophobic N-MIL@CNT and aromatic organic molecules. (3) Hydrogen bonding is generated between aminated MIL-53(Al) and organics containing the terminal -NH2 or -OH groups. (4) Interface synergy exists because of the active open cavities of CNT and the high affinity of aminated MIL-53(Al) facing organic molecules. The differences in the strength of the above interactions are responsible for the selective adsorption of various organic molecules, while they were adsorbed on the as-constructed N-MIL@CNT composites.

elements.content: N-MIL@CNT can be renewed by washing with ethanol and reapplied in sorption tests. Figure S11 demonstrates the cyclic adsorption capacity of BPAF and Metribuzin by N-MIL@CNT. For example, the removal rates of BPAF within the six cyclic adsorption processes are 93.3%, 93.45%, 93.5%, 91.1%, 91.7%, and 90.8%, and those for Metribuzin are 96.35%, 92%, 97.05%, 91.15%, 90.5%, and 89.5%. There is almost no change for the adsorption capacities of BPAF and Metribuzin undergoing six runs of adsorption procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Reusability and Stability

N-MIL@CNT can be renewed by washing with ethanol and reapplied in sorption tests. Figure S11 demonstrates the cyclic adsorption capacity of BPAF and Metribuzin by N-MIL@CNT. For example, the removal rates of BPAF within the six cyclic adsorption processes are 93.3%, 93.45%, 93.5%, 91.1%, 91.7%, and 90.8%, and those for Metribuzin are 96.35%, 92%, 97.05%, 91.15%, 90.5%, and 89.5%. There is almost no change for the adsorption capacities of BPAF and Metribuzin undergoing six runs of adsorption procedures.

elements.content: The PXRD profiles of N-MIL@CNT with adsorbed organics are shown in Figure S12, and the corresponding XRD profiles before the adsorption are also listed for comparison. It is noticed that a small shift (∼0.2°) of the locations of the XRD peaks is observed in comparison. According to reports, a breathing effect with respect to the temperature and the different guest molecules in the pores causes the geometrical distortions for MIL-53 and its functionalized derivates. On the basis of DFT calculations, for empty NH2-MIL-53­(Al), a monoclinic phase with a narrow pore is preferred, which may partly transform to an open configuration with large pores while incorporating guest molecules. These kinds of geometrical distortions may cause small XRD shifts. However, the main XRD peaks are still maintained, suggesting skeleton structure stability for N-MIL@CNT undergoing six cyclic adsorption processes.
elements.clean_text: The PXRD profiles of N-MIL@CNT with adsorbed organics are shown in Figure S12, and the corresponding XRD profiles before the adsorption are also listed for comparison. It is noticed that a small shift (~0.2°) of the locations of the XRD peaks is observed in comparison. According to reports, a breathing effect with respect to the temperature and the different guest molecules in the pores causes the geometrical distortions for MIL-53 and its functionalized derivates. On the basis of DFT calculations, for empty NH2-MIL-53(Al), a monoclinic phase with a narrow pore is preferred, which may partly transform to an open configuration with large pores while incorporating guest molecules. These kinds of geometrical distortions may cause small XRD shifts. However, the main XRD peaks are still maintained, suggesting skeleton structure stability for N-MIL@CNT undergoing six cyclic adsorption processes.

elements.content: In conclusion, a facile procedure combining the pyrolysis of MOFs and a typical in situ hydrothermal process is developed to construct the compact heterostructure of N-MIL@CNT for the first time. The resulting composites show remarkably improved adsorption activity and selectivity in the removal of BPAF and Metribuzin with high uptakes of 274 mg/g (BPAF) and 213 mg/g (Metribuzin) compared to those of a single CNT, aminated MIL-53­(Al), and other reported MOF-based nanocomposites. The synergistic effect aroused by the compact heterostructure is proven to be important in the efficient adsorption of organics. This adsorption behavior is featured in a Langmuir monomolecular layer and chemical adsorption, and the thermodynamics are described as endothermic, entropy-increasing, and spontaneous adsorption. The enhanced adsorption mechanism can be ascribed to π–π attraction forces, hydrogen bonding, and interface synergy. More importantly, the open cavities of CNT and the high affinity of aminated MIL-53­(Al) make the resulting composites excellent choices for the efficient removal of organic molecules. Our work opens new opportunities for developing hybrid materials using MOFs as the synthesis precursors for various applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a facile procedure combining the pyrolysis of MOFs and a typical in situ hydrothermal process is developed to construct the compact heterostructure of N-MIL@CNT for the first time. The resulting composites show remarkably improved adsorption activity and selectivity in the removal of BPAF and Metribuzin with high uptakes of 274 mg/g (BPAF) and 213 mg/g (Metribuzin) compared to those of a single CNT, aminated MIL-53(Al), and other reported MOF-based nanocomposites. The synergistic effect aroused by the compact heterostructure is proven to be important in the efficient adsorption of organics. This adsorption behavior is featured in a Langmuir monomolecular layer and chemical adsorption, and the thermodynamics are described as endothermic, entropy-increasing, and spontaneous adsorption. The enhanced adsorption mechanism can be ascribed to π-π attraction forces, hydrogen bonding, and interface synergy. More importantly, the open cavities of CNT and the high affinity of aminated MIL-53(Al) make the resulting composites excellent choices for the efficient removal of organic molecules. Our work opens new opportunities for developing hybrid materials using MOFs as the synthesis precursors for various applications.

cln_elements.content:
The whole synthetic process for aminated MIL-53­(Al) @CNT is explained in . ZIF-67 was prepared based on a former report. Typically, Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (1.644 g, 5.65 mmol) was added to methanol (80 mL), into which a solution of 2-methylimidazole (3.7 g, 45 mmol) and 80 mL of methanol was added. After stirring 24 h at 25 °C, ZIF-67 particles were obtained, washed with methanol, and then dried at 60 °C under vacuum. The pyrolysis of ZIF-67 follows the literal work. ZIF-67 was treated at 800 °C, kept for 2 h under a N2 atmosphere at 4 °C/min, then naturally cooled to room temperature to obtain cobalt-containing CNT (Co@CNT).

Aminated MIL-53­(Al)@CNT (labeled as N-MIL@CNT) was prepared based on a modified reported procedure. A total of 30 mg of Co@CNT was fully dispersed in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) under sonication, and then aminoisophthalic acid (NH2-BDC; 4.14 mmol, 0.75 g), AlCl3·6H2O (4.14 mmol, 1.0 g), and poly­(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP; 1.5 × 10–3 mmol, 60 mg) were added. After the mixed solution was stirred for 1 h, it was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-sealed autoclave and heat-treated at 140 °C for 24 h. The products were separated and washed by DMF to remove cobalt nanoparticles.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experiments

Synthesis of an Aminated MIL-53(Al)@CNT

The whole synthetic process for aminated MIL-53(Al) @CNT is explained in . ZIF-67 was prepared based on a former report. Typically, Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1.644 g, 5.65 mmol) was added to methanol (80 mL), into which a solution of 2-methylimidazole (3.7 g, 45 mmol) and 80 mL of methanol was added. After stirring 24 h at 25 °C, ZIF-67 particles were obtained, washed with methanol, and then dried at 60 °C under vacuum. The pyrolysis of ZIF-67 follows the literal work. ZIF-67 was treated at 800 °C, kept for 2 h under a N2 atmosphere at 4 °C/min, then naturally cooled to room temperature to obtain cobalt-containing CNT (Co@CNT).

Aminated MIL-53(Al)@CNT (labeled as N-MIL@CNT) was prepared based on a modified reported procedure. A total of 30 mg of Co@CNT was fully dispersed in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) under sonication, and then aminoisophthalic acid (NH2-BDC; 4.14 mmol, 0.75 g), AlCl3⋅6H2O (4.14 mmol, 1.0 g), and poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP; 1.5 × 10-3 mmol, 60 mg) were added. After the mixed solution was stirred for 1 h, it was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-sealed autoclave and heat-treated at 140 °C for 24 h. The products were separated and washed by DMF to remove cobalt nanoparticles.

cln_elements.content:
The morphology observation of the prepared particles is expressed in and S1. ZIF-67 (Figure S1a) looks like a diamond dodecahedron, the average side length of which is 200 nm. After calcination at 800 °C under a N2 atmosphere, a lot of the tube structure could be found on the surface of the diamond dodecahedron particles (a,b), and the nanotube diameter is about 3 nm on average (inset in b). The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of the resulting CNT represents two kinds of lattice structures: one with an interplanar spacing of 0.34 nm ascribed to the lattice plane (111) of metallic cobalt (JCPDS 15-0806) and the other one with d = 0.21 nm attributed to the plane (002) of graphitic carbon, which determines the generation of Co@CNT based on the pyrolysis of ZIF-67. The original aminated MIL-53­(Al) is irregular-shaped with a size of about 150 nm (Figure S1b). While aminated MIL-53­(Al) is synthesized in Co@CNT, as shown in d and S1c,d, lamellar-shaped MIL-53­(Al) with an average side length of about 200 nm is observed, and the compact heterostructure is produced between CNT and lamellar-shaped MIL-53­(Al). The inset in d illustrates the possible construction of a N-MIL@CNT composite nanostructure. The morphology changes of MIL-53­(Al) may be caused by the presence of CNT in the formation of MIL-53­(Al); in that case, heterogeneous nucleation instead of homogeneous nucleation may be conducted, and CNT acts as part of the nucleation center. A similar dependence is also reported in the synthesis of ZIF-8 in the presence of CNT, and the spherical-like ZIF-8 with smaller size is ornamented around the CNT sidewall, leading to the creation of a hierarchical pore structure. The elemental composition of N-MIL@CNT is given in Figure S1f, in which there are four elements (Al, N, O, and C), and the relative atomic percentages of C, N, O, and Al are 70.49%, 9.47%, 17.76%, and 2.22%, respectively. The Co cannot be found in the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy profile, indicating that Co may be removed in the construction of N-MIL@CNT due to HCl produced in the corresponding hydrothermal process.

The representative N2 sorption isotherm and corresponding pore size are depicted in g,h,i. The N2 sorption curves display a combined type I/IV sorption isotherm, implying the existence of both micropores and mesopores in Co@CNT, aminated MIL-53­(Al), and N-MIL@CNT. Furthermore, comparing the N2 adsorption–desorption curves of NH2-MIL-53­(Al) and N-MIL@CNT, we can find increased micropores and mesopores in N-MIL@CNT, and a distinct H4-type hysteresis loop at p/p 2 of more than 0.45 also indicated stacked pores by the lamellar structure in N-MIL@CNT. According to the corresponding pore-size distribution profile of N-MIL@CNT, there are mesopores centered at 2.5 nm in addition to the micropores. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) values of Co@CNT, aminated MIL-53­(Al), and N-MIL@CNT are 311.2, 319.1, and 811.1 m2/g, and the total pore volumes are 0.450, 0.574, and 0.662 cm3/g respectively. It should be noticed that the BET value and pore volume of N-MIL@CNT are both clearly larger than the values of aminated MIL-53 (Al) and Co@CNT, implying increased open channels and pores, which are beneficial for organics adsorption.

To estimate the theoretical maximum adsorption capacity, the sorption isotherms of the two organics were performed. With regard to a,b, the maximum equilibrium sorption capacities of BPAF are 175 mg/g (Co@CNT), 67 mg/g [aminated MIL-53­(Al)], and 270 mg/g (N-MIL@CNT), the values of which for Metribuzin are 85, 64, and 206 mg/g, respectively. The adsorption isotherms of the two organics by ZIF-67 were also measured, and the results are given in Figure S6. The maximum adsorption capacities of both organics are 47 mg/g (BPAF) and 12 mg/g (Metribuzin). Obviously, compared to the single component, N-MIL@CNT represents the excellent enhanced adsorption performance, which may result from the synergistic effect of the large open cavities of CNT and high affinity of aminated MIL-53­(Al).

Parts c–f of show the fitting curves replotted according to the Langmuir and Freundlich formulas, and the calculated isotherm constants are illustrated in . The highest correlation coefficients (R 2) and the closer values for the theoretical q max and experimental q e prove that the Langmuir pattern is more applicable for the two organics’ adsorption on N-MIL@CNT, and the theoretical q max values are 274 mg/g (BPAF) and 213.2 mg/g (Metribuzin), respectively. These results are larger than the formerly reported adsorption results of BPAF or Metribuzin by other adsorbents. For example, multiwalled CNT and chitosan-modified zeolite can adsorb BPAF with capacities of 88.89 and 26.2 mg/g; Metribuzin was absorbed by switch grass biochar and Mag-H+ with values of 151 and 65 mg/g.

The fitting results of the sorption isotherm by single aminated MIL-53­(Al) and Co@CNT represent the close R 2 by using the two isotherm equations, suggesting that the sorption on aminated MIL-53­(Al) and Co@CNT may feature in mixed adsorption behavior, and the theoretical q max values on Co@CNT are 209.2 mg/g (BPAF) and 104.7 mg/g (Metribuzin), much lower than that on N-MIL@CNT.

As displayed in a, most of the ions except Cu2+ have no significant negative impact on the BPAF adsorption, which can be well retained above 78% of the original value obtained without coexisting ions. The influence of other phenol organics (i.e., phenol, resorcinol, 3-aminophenol) on the BPAF adsorption was also studied to further verify the selectivity. As shown in b, the adsorption capacities are 159.5 mg/g (BPAF), 9.8 mg/g (phenol), 5.9 mg/g (resorcinol), and 11.8 mg/g (3-aminophenol). The excellent adsorption selectivity for BPAF by the as-constructed N-MIL@CNT is well presented, mainly thanks to the high affinity of aminated MIL-53­(Al) with BPAF via hydrogen bonding as well as the interface synergy brought by the compact heterostructure. In addition, we also conducted selective adsorption studies on Metribuzin. As presented in Figure S9, the adsorption capacities are 150.0 mg/g (Metribuzin), 15.9 mg/g (Tartrazine), 14.0 mg/g (Acid Blue 90), and 16.2 mg/g (Acid Blue 1). The excellent adsorption selectivity for Metribuzin could be explained by hydrogen bonding between Metribuzin and N-MIL@CNT.

Reusability and Stability

N-MIL@CNT can be renewed by washing with ethanol and reapplied in sorption tests. Figure S11 demonstrates the cyclic adsorption capacity of BPAF and Metribuzin by N-MIL@CNT. For example, the removal rates of BPAF within the six cyclic adsorption processes are 93.3%, 93.45%, 93.5%, 91.1%, 91.7%, and 90.8%, and those for Metribuzin are 96.35%, 92%, 97.05%, 91.15%, 90.5%, and 89.5%. There is almost no change for the adsorption capacities of BPAF and Metribuzin undergoing six runs of adsorption procedures.
